data.title: Catalog
data.meta_description: During a revolution on a small Caribbean Island, international playboy and promoter Renzo Capeto uses his boat to help a group of loyalists headed by Colonel Tostada escape with the national treasury which they plan to use to stage a counterrevolution. Capeto plans to seize the money and claim that a mythological monster rose out of the sea and devoured the loyalists. Unknown to him, a real monster lurks in the very waters where he plans to kill his passengers. When the creature upsets his plans, Capeto decides to sink his boat in 30 feet of water and then retrieve the treasure. Using a nearby island for a base, he and his gang attempt to salvage the loot, but the monster picks them off one by one, except for secret service agent Sparks Moran and his girl friend Mango.
data.text:
In a keynote speech given at the thirteenth annual Motion Picture Seminar of the Northwest, producer-director Roger Corman stated that he was “so tired of monster movie formulas” by the time he made Creature from the Haunted Sea, he decided to end the film “with the monster killing the entire cast, then sitting on their bones and picking his teeth,” as quoted in an 11 Jun 1980 Var article. The production was filmed in Puerto Rico in 1959. One of the cast members was Academy-Award-winning screenwriter and director Robert Towne, who played “Sparks Moran” under the pseudonym “Edward Wain.”

An item in the 25 May 1960 DV stated that Roger Corman’s company, The Filmgroup, Inc., planned to release the picture in Aug 1960. Months later, the 2 Nov 1960 Var indicated the film would be released on 8 Dec 1960 on a double-bill with The Devil’s Partner (1961, see entry), prior to an 8 Feb 1961 DV announcement that theatrical release was scheduled to take place in Apr 1961. The film eventually opened with The Devil’s Partner in Los Angeles, CA, the week of 27 Jul 1962. A review in the 27 Jul 1962 LAT deemed both pictures “sub-standard.”

On 7 Jul 1961, a DV news brief stated that Corman was brokering a deal with United Artists TV for the television rights to fifteen Filmgroup pictures, including Creature from the Haunted Sea. All of the films were set to be theatrically released prior to their television debuts.

Two years after the film was released, a casting announcement in ...

More Less

In a keynote speech given at the thirteenth annual Motion Picture Seminar of the Northwest, producer-director Roger Corman stated that he was “so tired of monster movie formulas” by the time he made Creature from the Haunted Sea, he decided to end the film “with the monster killing the entire cast, then sitting on their bones and picking his teeth,” as quoted in an 11 Jun 1980 Var article. The production was filmed in Puerto Rico in 1959. One of the cast members was Academy-Award-winning screenwriter and director Robert Towne, who played “Sparks Moran” under the pseudonym “Edward Wain.”

An item in the 25 May 1960 DV stated that Roger Corman’s company, The Filmgroup, Inc., planned to release the picture in Aug 1960. Months later, the 2 Nov 1960 Var indicated the film would be released on 8 Dec 1960 on a double-bill with The Devil’s Partner (1961, see entry), prior to an 8 Feb 1961 DV announcement that theatrical release was scheduled to take place in Apr 1961. The film eventually opened with The Devil’s Partner in Los Angeles, CA, the week of 27 Jul 1962. A review in the 27 Jul 1962 LAT deemed both pictures “sub-standard.”

On 7 Jul 1961, a DV news brief stated that Corman was brokering a deal with United Artists TV for the television rights to fifteen Filmgroup pictures, including Creature from the Haunted Sea. All of the films were set to be theatrically released prior to their television debuts.

Two years after the film was released, a casting announcement in the 1 Jul 1963 DV indicated that Michael Mark had been cast in Roger Corman’s Creature from the Haunted Sea. It is unclear whether or not the item was published at the wrong time or contained erroneous information, or both. In a 1988 interview, cult director Monte Hellman stated that Roger Corman asked him to expand four movies for television--they reportedly needed to be 80 minutes to sell them to Allied Artists' TV. Hellman said that he reshot scenes for Beast from Haunted Cave, Creature from the Haunted Sea, Last Woman on Earth and Ski Troop Attack. Although Mark did not appear in Creature from the Haunted Sea, the casting announcement could have been related to the reshoot.

Less

Capeto plans to seize the money and claim that a mythological monster rose out of the sea and devoured the loyalists. Unknown to him, a real monster lurks in the very waters where he plans to kill his passengers. When the creature upsets his plans, Capeto decides to sink his boat in 30 feet of water and then retrieve the treasure. Using a nearby island for a base, he and his gang attempt to salvage the loot, but the monster picks them off one by one, except for secret service agent Sparks Moran and his girl friend ...

During a revolution on a small Caribbean Island, international playboy and promoter Renzo Capeto uses his boat to help a group of loyalists headed by Colonel Tostada escape with the national treasury which they plan to use to stage a counterrevolution. Capeto plans to seize the money and claim that a mythological monster rose out of the sea and devoured the loyalists. Unknown to him, a real monster lurks in the very waters where he plans to kill his passengers. When the creature upsets his plans, Capeto decides to sink his boat in 30 feet of water and then retrieve the treasure. Using a nearby island for a base, he and his gang attempt to salvage the loot, but the monster picks them off one by one, except for secret service agent Sparks Moran and his girl friend Mango.
